unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Sports Drinks: Null and Alternative Hypotheses
question_text:
Suppose a random survey was taken in a large urban high school to determine if vending machine location affects whether sports drinks are more likely to be ordered.
A large single sample of size n = $500$ was taken over the last week. In the cafeteria, $78$ of the $165$ drinks purchased were sports drinks. In the gym, $98$ of the $157$ drinks purchased were sports drinks, and in the auditorium, $54$ of the $178$ drinks purchased were sports drinks.
What are the appropriate null and alternative hypotheses?

choices.text:
$H_o:$ There is no relationship between location and preferring sports drink
$H_a:$ A higher proportion of drinks purchased in the gym are sports drinks

$H_o:$ Location and preferring a sports drink are not independent
$H_a:$ Location and preferring a sports drink are independent

$H_o:$ No association exists between location and preferring a sports drink
$H_a:$ An association exists between location and preferring a sports drink

$H_o:$ There is no relationship between the number of sports drinks ordered at each location
$H_a:$ There is a relation between the number of sports drinks ordered at each location

$H_o:$ Sports drinks and preference are homogeneous
$H_a:$ Sports drinks and preference are not homogeneous
